column5:
Your wound failed to heal through primary intention. There was an issue in the proliferation stage of healing where angiogenesis occurs, essentially blood flow was compromised causing necrosis. 

Patient movement is also a big reason for complications, pulling and moving against sutures. 

Suture ligatures being too tight are also a potential for epidermal damage. They looked fine from what I can see. 

Sometimes these things happen and thereâ€™s no one to blame. The body can be so resilient at times but fail at something simple.

I find it hard to believe that it was negligence on the Doctors part. 

Iâ€™ve assisted with cesarean sections where we stretch incisions to at least double and also blunt dissected incisions frequently. 

Thereâ€™s minor bruising, sutures look fine with several anchor sutures for stability. Sutures should have stayed for 14 days minimum with supportive dressings to prevent dehiscence (which is what happened). 

From there chronic wound management with wet dressings, packing and anti microbial agents like silver and antibiotics post wound swabs.

Iâ€™ve honestly never seen excessive stretching. Iâ€™m glad itâ€™s healed, shame that it was so traumatic.
Bloody Footscrazy is at it again.

I also have TRD, being on a pharmacy of drugs and having physical interventions like Transcranial magnetic stimulation and ECT arenâ€™t effective for me still. Therapy too. 

Ketamine trials where I am are very rigid and only the Esketamine with intranasal administration are being looked at. The studies that Iâ€™ve looked at require long term ongoing infusions for optimal treatment, what are the doctors saying about longevity?

How do you find yourself compared to before commencing the trial?

My next treatment option is Vagal Nerve Stimulation. Itâ€™s not fair is it?
Itâ€™s called a â€˜Floofenâ€™ in the cat page I follow.

I canâ€™t seem to find any documents, just plenty of news articles without definitive answers. Interviews say that all their cadavers are donated with consent when theyâ€™re alive and of natural causes. Wether or not theyâ€™re truthful is another thing.
I doubt it there are tens of thousands of people who have signed up for body donation to be plastinated. Where did you hear this crap?

It can be manipulative but it can also be true and a term of endearment. Sometimes itâ€™s hard to love other people when you canâ€™t even bare to be alive and thereâ€™s this huge self loathing. Holding onto someone who is â€˜normalâ€™ is like a life raft, maybe they will be able to help. 

Itâ€™s hard to put in as much work when youâ€™re so unwell that existing is hard. Itâ€™s also hard on the other person, OP should be preserving their own mentality too. Talking to a professional can help consolidate feelings and understand situations. Itâ€™s easy to fall into the frustration and anger associated with watching your partner be reduced to nothing.

Story time,

I graduated from University in late 2018 and started a Graduate Year as an RN in early 2019 which is kinda like a 12 month apprenticeship program. 

So unfortunately I suffer from treatment resistant depression which I had been managing marginally over the last 3 years with a crap tonne of medication and other physical therapies. 

About 3 months into the program I couldnâ€™t manage my depression anymore and was suicidal, I went into hospital to work on myself. I ended up not responding to most treatments and required Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). I pretty much remember nothing from the time I was in hospital but I know it was the worst time of my life. 

I slowly got back my ability to recall short term memory and came back to work after being away  from early April â€˜19 to late June â€˜19. So about three months. I went back to work and you wouldnâ€™t have noticed the internal struggles Iâ€™ve been facing. 

So I finished up the â€˜apprenticeshipâ€™ on January 31st and was given this certificate. Iâ€™m not sure how I could have partially completed a graduate year and get a certificate of completion. 

Itâ€™s kinda funny but equally sad that my workplace couldnâ€™t overlook what happened, this isnâ€™t even a certificate for university studies but an in-house award. An appreciation award. 

I canâ€™t hang this because every time Iâ€™ll look at Iâ€™ll be reminded that I couldnâ€™t complete something because of my illness.

Iâ€™ve been a RN for 12 months, a grad year is my â€˜apprenticeshipâ€™ year. I was a different grade nurse beforehand for 3 years too. 

The certificate is from my previous workplace, luckily my real certificate is normal. Thank you though!

Itâ€™s interesting the different requirements in different countries. In Australia all physicians and nurses are registered with a governing body called AHPRA which allows the public to see if they have any conditions or undertakings of practice. Also wether or not they have prescription rights. 

NPâ€™s are instrumental for our regional and rural areas. Having said that everyone works quite closely with the MDâ€™s, egos are dangerous. This poor girl shouldnâ€™t have died.
Iâ€™ve successfully completed my grad year partially. What a weird sentence.
Blunt affect and tone can be a side effect of depression but again doesnâ€™t mean that peopleâ€™s thought processes are any less indicative of his true thoughts.

Since when does depression stop people from expressing opinions? Itâ€™s not like we turn into living breathing potatoes. 

Donâ€™t discredit someone from what theyâ€™ve expressed because theyâ€™re potentially depressed. Just because he had a traumatic experience doesnâ€™t mean that he ceases all rational thought patterns because you donâ€™t like his response.

I recently looked after a guy that had let a SCC on his face eat away his tissue on the right side of  his face. I could see his tempromandibular joint and through into his mouth. 

You know in The Mummy when Imhotep starts to get tissue again? Yep just like that. Poor guy stunk.

Surely you would ensure that your couplings meet your local requirements? 

Plus the CFA and RFS use 65mm couplings. The RFS information is harder to find though.
Howâ€™d you find building to BAL29 specs? Iâ€™m anticipating a moderate BAL assessment.
I believe itâ€™s just for properties that arenâ€™t connected to mains water. The bigger the property the more water tanks needed. I have 5 acres and only need 10,000L but I have a dam too.
Itâ€™s the home owners responsibility to ensure they have the right attachments as per the CFA requirements which is documented online.
Thankfully having 10,000L steel tanks with pumps and CFA couplings are requirements when building in Rural Residential areas.
Or kill him, withdrawal is nasty business.
Watch â€˜The man from U.N.C.L.Eâ€™ if you want some spy Henry.
This better be satire, only idiots with no ability differentiate between the Governments scapegoating and the truth believe this nonsense.

We normally catch and release outside but my husband got spooked and dropped the container, the poor thing ran to the recliner and we werenâ€™t able to release it. Unfortunately no matter what I do to desensitise myself to spiders Iâ€™m still deathly afraid. 

Snakes are fine though, my brain is flawed.
Yeah, my husband squealed the other day because of the sheer size of this Huntsman. Theyâ€™re super fast and this one hid in a recliner. If it wasnâ€™t found I was checking into a hotel.
I get that but still his decision making could have been impaired at the time of being pulled out of sedation. I watched the video, itâ€™s a gray area.

Thatâ€™s still not consent or even informed consent. 
How could we know if thatâ€™s what he actually wanted without the significant pharmacological intervention.  

I would have been incredibly uncomfortable asking someone in his situation about what he wanted.
A+ for public relations, could go either way.
Happy to be of service!

Youâ€™re correct, I completely forgot about that. I was incorrect in the way I said that. I was meaning that the police force is more likely to use non lethal interventions but I completely missed the mark.

I apologise I shouldnâ€™t use absolutes, youâ€™re correct. Iâ€™m not an LEO but I am a nurse and unfortunately we get assaulted more than we should. We work closely with law enforcement and I base my opinions on cases where similar situations have occurred in Aus where life was preserved. 

Ultimately I wasnâ€™t present and donâ€™t have police training. I have such respect for police officers and the sacrifices they make for the community. I asked a question which was downvoted and I thought opening a discussion from another country would be an interesting comparison. I was wrong VicPol are nowhere near perfect but respect them dearly and think they do an incredible job.
No I asked wether the police officer could have aimed for limbs instead of the trunk. I was told that they donâ€™t train the officers to do that and to aim for central mass.

I live rurally, thereâ€™s definitely a lot more up here. Pest control and hunting, I havenâ€™t come across a GSW wound to patch up yet, lots of idiots with power tools. Itâ€™s like people think that they can afford to loose a digit or two.

Our police are less likely to use their guns or even unholster their gun. They work in pairs and are more likely to use non lethal interventions. If there is a fatality the coroners court work with the police force to ensure that training policies and procedures are up to standard and where they can improve outcomes.

Iâ€™m talking about this situation. I know that there are well executed non lethal interventions performed by the police in the US. 

This situation in a different country may have ended differently due to staffing, training and the individual. My police force is less likely to use lethal force, I believe that the outcome may have been different. Thatâ€™s all.

My police force is VicPol, look they understand that a good chunk of people theyâ€™re coming across have mental health issues. Our police work is pairs which enables them to try an create the best possible outcome for all. 

Iâ€™m offering a different opinion from a different part of the world where fatalities are significantly lower.

According to Australian statistics 5 people annually are killed from police intervention. That is incredibly low. All Iâ€™m saying is that our police force is less likely to use lethal force. I never said that people only get shot in the US, the truth is that there is reported to be at least 400 people and as much as 800 are killed by police in America each year (the data is poor). 

Iâ€™m not attacking anyone personally or trying to offend anyone, Iâ€™m offering a different outlook from a different country where they operate differently.

Iâ€™m only going on what my police force does. Having said that if someone said they had a gun here it would likely be untrue. 

My police force utilises non-lethal techniques and are successful. Also most of our police have partners and wonâ€™t attend a potentially violent call without backup. The police here rarely use lethality and officers can go full careers without removing their guns from their holsters. 

We have incredibly strict gun laws and only a small percentage have them. That means that when the police come up against potentially lethal threats they are coming up against knifes and other hand held weapons. they also understand the mental health issues that can be associated with such situations and have additional training as well as mental health clinicians.
I appreciate your answer, thank you for replying
VicPol are different. I donâ€™t know what more to say.  They rarely use lethal force.
We are coming into summer, itâ€™s already too hot. I mean at least we canâ€™t carry and get branded. The seatbelt is bad enough.

We get notified if a police officer discharged their weapon by a televised conference from our top cop. Thatâ€™s the transparency Iâ€™m talking about. Our police are more likely to discharge their weapon to put a kangaroo out of pain. 

Wherever you are I hope you stay safe!

The abdominal aorta, mesenteric arteries, hepatic arteries, spleen, liver, a shit tonne of cardiac vessels. When you go into shock the body decreases blood flow to the limbs to protect the trunk. 

Iâ€™m not saying the femoral artery isnâ€™t fatal itâ€™s just not as fatal as being hit in the trunk. The femoral artery is quite deep too. Food for thought.

Thereâ€™s been documented situations exactly like this one where VicPol apprehended the person without killing them. Actually itâ€™s incredibly rare for a police officer using a firearm against a citizen. Our police force is very transparent in its dealings and their outcomes. 

Only recently we had 4 die from a mass shooting but that has been the first in 2 decades. Someone who lives in the US canâ€™t understand how people like us can live without guns and vice versa.

Iâ€™m talking in regarding this situation. Our officers would have treated this situation differently and that person would be alive. 

I donâ€™t need a to carry a gun to feel safe. We had a mass shooting and our gun laws changed significantly to protect us from further mass shootings. Our citizens willingly gave up their guns for future safety. 

Iâ€™ve never had to come across an GSW or even held a gun.  Our police officers arenâ€™t coming up against militia style firearms or needlessly loosing their lives because of that.

In Australia we donâ€™t have access to firearms like the US, we donâ€™t really have gun ranges and anyone who handles a gun needs a licence as well as short course on firearm safety. Handguns are pretty much nonexistent and require a different licence and no citizen can lawfully carry a firearm on their person. 

What Iâ€™m saying is that when my police officers are in these situations they handle things differently and rarely end in a fatality. Youâ€™ll find that our police will often go through their whole career without using their guns or even removing them from their holster.

Your law enforcement is trained in centre mass, my law enforcement isnâ€™t. My law enforcement rarely uses their firearms and utilise non-lethal interventions. 

Anatomy wise thatâ€™s incorrect. Youâ€™re able to tourniquet legs but you canâ€™t do that to a torso. Youâ€™re more likely to hit major arteries aiming at centre mass.
I can see where youâ€™re coming from but a bullet to the chest is more lethal than hitting the legs. You can tourniquet legs but a bullet to the chest/abdomen is significantly more lethal.
What about hitting legs and arms instead of the trunk? Iâ€™m just curious, thanks for answering.
Pardon my ignorance but could have the officer useful non-lethal tactics? Iâ€™m from Aus where this just doesnâ€™t happen very often.
Thereâ€™s four months where I refuse to even talk about or try to recollect anything that happened during my ECT. Itâ€™s just that frustrating.

No one with known illness should handle an infant and should be up to date with their vaccinations which includes the Flu Vax. 

Depending on wether the meningitis was viral or bacterial, you can kind of figure out the transmission. Viral meningitis is likely to come from your in-laws where bacterial is likely to come from direct droplet precautions from a carrier who can be anyone who has had contact. Including your immediate family. 

They should have refrained from visiting but depending on type of meningitis they may not be the cause of the infection.
